## Data Visualization 

From Wikipedia:

"R is a programming language and free software environment for statistical computing and **graphics** ... ." 

There are three major graphical systems: 

- R base graphics
- `lattice`
- `ggplot2`

In this course, we will focus on `ggplot2`. If you want to learn about the others, 
[R Graphics](https://www.crcpress.com/R-Graphics/Murrell/p/book/9780429196119)
is a great source. 

---
class: left, top

## ggplot2
What is **ggplot2**?

- an R package for data visualisation 
- implementation of the [Grammar of Graphics](https://www.springer.com/de/book/9781475731002) in R
- part of the [tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org/)

Some interesting links: 

- [R for Data Science](http://r4ds.had.co.nz/) 
- [ggplot2: Elegant graphics for data Analysis](http://moderngraphics11.pbworks.com/f/ggplot2-Book09hWickham.pdf)
- [R Graphics Cookbook](http://www.cookbook-r.com/Graphs/)
- [R Graph Gallery](https://www.r-graph-gallery.com/)
- [DataCamp](https://www.datacamp.com/courses/data-visualization-with-ggplot2-1)

---
class: left, top
## The Layered Grammer of Graphics

The grammar consists of 
- data
- aesthetic mappings (e.g. mapping of data to x and y coordinates, size, color, shape, ...)
- geometric objects (e.g. points, lines, bars, ...)
- scales (controls mapping from data to aesthetics  e.g. which colors should be used)
- facets (splitting data to create plots for subgroups)
- statistical transformations (summarize data before plotting)
- coordinate systems (e.g. Cartesian, semi-log, polar, ...)

The data along with mappings, geometric objects and transformations form a layer. A plot can have multiple layers. 

---
class: left, top
## A Basic Example

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
data("diamonds")
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price))
```

`ggplot()`

- Creates a coordinate system that you can add layers to.
- Everything you provide as an argument here will be the default for all added layers.

`geom_point()`

- Adds a layer of points.
- Each `geom_*` function takes a mapping argument which, paired with `aes()`, defines how variables are mapped to visuals.

---
class: left, top
## A Basic Example

```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
library(ggplot2)
set.seed(321)
data("diamonds")
diamonds <- diamonds[sample(1:nrow(diamonds), 5000), ]
ggplot(data = diamonds) + geom_point(mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price))
```

---
class: left, top
## Adding Layers

For better visibility of a (possibly nonlinear) relationship we add a smoothing function to the plot.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price)) +
  geom_smooth(mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price), method = 'loess')
```

For more compact code we may
- omit parameter names 
- specify `mapping` in `ggplot()`.    

  
The same mapping is then used for all layers (but may be overwritten, if necessary).

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = 'loess')
```

---
class: left, top
## Adding a Layer

```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = 'loess')
```

## Aesthetics

- Each geom has its own set of aesthetics.
- Until now we only used the x and y coordinates as aesthetics.
- `?geom_point()` tells us about further aesthetics that we can map data to in a point plot. 

Let's use distinct shapes for different qualities of `cut`.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price,
                     color = color, shape =  cut)) + 
  geom_point()
```

---
class: left, top
## Aesthetics

```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}

                     color = color, shape =  cut)) + 
  geom_point()
```

## Statistic  Transformations and Aesthetics

- `ggplot()` automatically groups the data when  discrete variables are mapped to aesthetics
- In this case every statistic transformation is performed *by group*.


```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE, warning=FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, 
                     color = color, shape =  cut)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth()
```

---
class: left, top
## Statitic Transformations and Aesthetics
```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = color, shape =  cut)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

---
class: left, top
## Statitic Transformations and Aesthetics
- If this is not desired simply provide `color` and `shape` as additional aesthetics to `geom_point()`
    ```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = color, shape = cut)) +
  geom_smooth()
    ```
- It sometimes is more convenient to gather all aesthetics in `ggplot()` (e.g. if there are many layers) and overwrite groups by an arbitrary value.
    ```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, 
                     color = color, shape = cut)) + 
  geom_point() +  
  geom_smooth(aes(group = 1))
    ```

---
class: left, top
## Statistic Transformations and Aesthetics
```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = color, shape = cut)) + 
  geom_point() +
  stat_smooth(aes(group = 1))
```

class: left, top
## Geometric Objects and Statistic Transformations

- Layers may be defined in terms of a geometric object (`geom_*`) or a statistic transformation (`stat_*`).
- Each geometric object is associated with a default statistic transformation and vice versa.
    
    **Examples**: 
    
    - `geom_point()` has the identity function as statistic transformation.
    
    - `geom_smooth()` fits a regression model before plotting a line with a prediction interval.
    
    `stat_smooth()` is an alias which does essentially the same, however, in the first case we could change the statistic transformation and in the second case we could change the geometric object.
- Often it is not a good idea to change the default behaviour (e.g. try  `geom_point(stat = "smooth", method = "lm")`) but we will see an example where it can be useful.

## Bar Plot
`geom_bar()` counts the number of observations within each group and produces a bar plot. 
```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = TRUE, out.width='50%'}
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = cut)) # x should be discreate
```

## Faceting
- `facet_grid()` allows to generate multiple plots, each showing a different subset of the data.
- Faceting helps to compare patterns across different groups of observations.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE, out.width='50%'}
ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price))  + 
  geom_point() + 
  stat_density2d(aes(fill = ..level..), geom = "polygon") + 
  facet_grid( ~ cut)
```

---
class: left, top
## Faceting using one variable
```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price))  + 
  geom_point() + 
   stat_density2d(aes(fill = ..level..), geom = "polygon") + 
  facet_grid( ~ cut)
```

---
class: left, top
## Faceting using two variables
```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price))  + 
  geom_point() + 
   stat_density2d(aes(fill = ..level..), geom = "polygon") + 
  facet_grid(color  ~ cut)
```

class: left, top
## Position Adjustments
- Each geometric object has a parameter for position adjustment.
- In the following example, we dividebthe bar plot into groups defined by `clarity`.
    ```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(data = diamonds) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = cut, fill = clarity),
           position = "stack") # the default
    ```
- Instead of stacking the bars we may position them side-by-side using `dodge`. 
    ```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
  geom_bar(., position = "dodge") 
    ```
- Relative proportions are easily visulised by stacking the bars and standardising them to have the same height using `fill`.
    ```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
geom_bar(., position = "fill") 
    ```

## Scales
- Scales determine how the data are mapped to the aesthetics.
- A scale is defined by a function of the form `scale_aestheticname_scalename()`

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = TRUE, out.width='50%'}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price, color = cut)) + geom_point() + scale_color_grey()
```

---
class: left, top
## Scales
It is also possible to use custom scales.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = TRUE, out.width='50%'}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price, color = cut)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("#c9792e", "blue", "green", "gray", "thistle2"))
```

## Titles and labels 

`labs()` allows you to
- add a title and a subtitle
- add a caption
- add a tag
- change the axis labels
- change the legend title

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, fill = cut)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Diamanten", x = "Karat", y = "Preis", fill = "Schnitt") 
```

---
class: left, top

```{r, echo = FALSE, eval = TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, fill = cut)) + 
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Diamanten", x = "Karat", y = "Preis", fill = "Schnitt") 
```

class: left, top
## Themes

Themes control the appearance of the plot. Think of them as a set of graphical parameters which define

- font type and font size
- background
- ticks marks and labels
- grid lines
- ...

There are many predefined themes, however, if you like you can set up your own ones.

```{r, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price, color = cut)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  theme_bw()
```

---
class: left, top
## Themes

```{r}

  geom_point() + theme_bw()
```

## Exercises 

1. Follow the instructions for the Titanic data set (download from Moodle).

  - Use a bar plot to show how many people survived the Titanic compared to those who didn't. 
  - Add a color coding to the previous plot to visualize the differences between the passengers' genders.
  - Split the previous plot into three plots based on the passengers class. 
  - Compare the distribution of age for the survivors and non-survivors.  

<ol start="2">
<li> Try to answer the following questions about the <TT>mpg</TT> dataset (comes with <TT>ggplot2</TT>) using <TT>ggplot</TT>.  </li>
</ol>
<ul>
  <ul>
    <li> How are engine size and fuel economy related?</li>
    <li> Do certain manufacturers care more about economy than others?</li>
    <li> Has fuel economy improved in the last ten years?</li>
    </ul>
</ul>

<ol start="3">
<li> Compare the two data sets  <TT>economics</TT> and <TT>economics_long</TT> (both come with <TT>ggplot</tt>) with respect to the ease of use when working with <TT>ggplot</TT>.</li>

```{r, eval = FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
titanic <- read.csv(here::here("datasets", "titanic.csv"), dec = ",")

write.csv(titanic, file = here::here("datasets", "titanic.csv"))

ggplot(titanic) + geom_bar(aes(x = survived, fill = sex), position = "dodge")
ggplot(titanic) + geom_bar(aes(x = survived, fill = sex), position = "dodge") + facet_wrap(~pclass)
ggplot(titanic) + geom_bar(aes(x = survived, fill = sex), position = "dodge") + facet_wrap( ~age < 15)
ggplot(titanic) + geom_density(aes(x = age, col = survived), position = "dodge")  + facet_grid( pclass~sex)
ggplot(titanic) + geom_density(aes(x = age, col = survived), position = "dodge")  + facet_grid( pclass~sex)
ggplot(titanic,aes(x = fare, y = age, col = survived)) + geom_point(position = "dodge")  + facet_grid( pclass~sex) + geom_smooth()
```
